script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, Genesis 5 reads like a long list of names from Adam to Noah, but then there's this one line that stops you in your tracks: 'And Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him' from Genesis 5:24. What do you make of that mysterious verse?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's the perfect place to start, David. Moses 6 fills in the incredible details we miss in Genesis. It shows Enoch's humility, his doubts, and how God turned him into a mighty prophet.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that. Tell me more about Enoch's call. Why did he feel so overwhelmed?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6:26–36, Enoch says he's a 'lad' and slow of speech, like others might mock him. He asks why him when there are better men. It's relatable—he saw his own weaknesses clearly.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's fascinating. From Enoch's perspective, he felt totally inadequate. But what did the Lord say to encourage him?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The Lord reassures him in Moses 6:32–34: 'As I live, even so will I come in the meridian of time... Lift up your heart and rejoice... Walk with me.' It's this beautiful invitation to partnership. God saw Enoch's potential despite his fears.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued by that phrase 'Walk with me' from Moses 6:34. It feels so personal. How did that play out for Enoch?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Verses 37–47 show the Lord empowering him. Enoch prophesied, and great miracles happened—the earth trembled, and Zion was built. What strikes me is how God supports us when we step out in faith.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a profound connection. It reminds me of other prophets who felt the same way. Have you noticed a pattern there?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Think of Moses saying he's slow of speech in Exodus 4:10, or Jeremiah feeling too young. Even Nephi and Moroni struggled with their weaknesses. Yet God calls us anyway, just like Enoch.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hadn't thought of it that way across those stories. So the pattern is God choosing the humble and weak to do His work.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and it builds to something remarkable in Moses 6. After Enoch's ministry, we shift to Adam learning the full gospel plan.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Walk me through that. What did Adam discover?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6:48–68, Adam asks in verse 53, 'Why is it that thou hast called me, saying: Teach these things unto this people... that they may be born again?' The Lord explains faith in Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism by water, and receiving the Holy Ghost.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's powerful. Notice how baptism is tied to being 'born again' in verse 59. What does that symbol reveal?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Water represents rebirth, washing away the old life. It's a symbol pointing straight to the Savior's doctrine from the very beginning. And verse 7 says this priesthood 'was in the beginning [and] shall be in the end of the world also'—timeless truth.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What many don't realize is how early parents were commanded to teach this. How does that fit in?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6:51–62, the Lord tells Adam, 'Teach these things freely unto your children.' It's faith, repentance, baptism, Holy Ghost—the first principles. Parents kept a book of remembrance to pass it down.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's significant. Sin had spread, as in Moses 6:15 with Satan's dominion, but righteous parents taught the ways of God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. Despite sin blinding eyes, dulling ears, and hardening hearts—like in Moses 6:27 and 35—Enoch and Adam saw clearly through faith. God softened their hearts with clay, opening eyes to truth.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Those symbols deepen it all. From Enoch's doubts to Adam's baptismal truths, it's one continuous pattern of redemption.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It mirrors how God works across dispensations. Ancient families faced the same principles we do today.

script.speaker: David
script.text: How does this apply to us now, especially when we feel like Enoch?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: When God calls us—to teach our families, serve, or repent—He knows our weaknesses. Like Enoch, we can walk with Him. Modern prophets reflect that, feeling inadequate yet strengthened.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a realization that really deepens my understanding. So the invitation is personal.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes. Accept the call to teach these truths at home, keep your own book of remembrance, and let God empower you.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this has been transformative. Thanks for uncovering these connections. Listeners, study Moses 6 this week and hear the Lord's call to walk with Him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It's been a joy, David. May we all lift our hearts and rejoice in His promises.
